part.text: C4Script supports the following data types for variables, parameters, and return values:

row.col: "true" (value true) or "false" (value false). Expected as parameter by many structures such as if and while.
A type containing multiple variables, whose number can be enquired with GetLength, and which can be recalled with array[index].
A general purpose object type. GetProperty and SetProperty can get respectively set properties. If the property "Prototype" is set, and a property that is not set is gotten, the prototype is asked.
Reference to an existing object at runtime. No direct representation. See FindObject()
When used as a function parameter type, the type check is skipped.
ID of an object definition (see Object Definitions).Will be changed into a proplist immediately.

part.text: Arrays can be created directly with [expression 1, expression 2, ...] or indirectly with CreateArray(). They are automatically enlarged if necessary on element access, but it's faster to create them with the needed length from the start. If an array is stored in a variable or used as a parameter to a function, the new variable has it's own copy of the array. The actual copy is deferred if possible, though. If an array is passed to a function for modification, a reference has to be used.
Access to element i of array a is achieved through a[i]. i=0 is the first element. Negative indices are counted from the end of the array, so that a[-1] refers to the last element of the array.

A range within an array can be copied with a[i:j]. The resulting array contains all elements with indices in the half-open interval [i,j). Negative indices are treated as when accessing single elements. Both indices are optional and assumed as 0 and GetLength(a) respectively if not given.

Proplists are a datatype that maps values to strings and supports prototype inheritance.
Proplists can be created with {key 1=expression 1, key 2=expression 2, ...} or with CreateProplist.

ul.li: All values except for false, nil and 0 are treated as true when a bool is required.
nil and false can be converted to 0. true can be converted to 1.
nil can always be used as a function parameter, if the function doesn't implement a separate check.
If an object has been converted into a proplist then it can be converted back to an object. Otherwise proplists cannot be converted into objects.
